table-wrap.anchoringText: Foam capacity to reduce steam mobility is influenced by experimental conditions: pressure, temperature, surfactant formulation choice and concentration, continuous injection or slugs, foam quality, steam quality, non-condensable gas injection, interstitial velocity, oil saturation, etc. Complexity arises largely from the interdependency of these experimental parameters. Therefore, no simple approach can be adopted. We choose to focus on some parameters to compare and summarize a selection of research work describing steam foam coreflood experiments. For the sake of clarity, Table 1 compares experimental protocols of presented research works.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Experimental parameters of research work

tr.td: Vertical, flow from bottom to top
Cold lake or Athabasca oil sand cores

table-wrap.anchoringText: As mentioned in the introduction, over 30 documented field tests have been performed and thousands of slugs of surfactant have been injected (Cooke & Eson, 1991). Table 2 lists all the published field tests in chronological order.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: List of field tests by chronological order

formatted-caption.caption-text: List of field tests by chronological order

table-wrap.anchoringText: Cook and Eson (Cooke & Eson, 1991) reported over a thousand cycles of surfactants in the Potter Sand of the giant Midway-Sunset field in California conducted by various operators. The results are summarized inTable 3. Unfortunately, very little detail is available and the nature of the various surfactants used was not disclosed.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Summary of steam foam tests in Midway-Sunset field, California (Cooke & Eson, 1991)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of steam foam tests in Midway-Sunset field, California (Cooke & Eson, 1991)

linkTarget.bib: CookeR., & Eson, Eson, R. (1991). Field Results of Optimizing the Steam Foam Diversion Process in Cyclic Steam Applications. Paper SPE 21531 presented at the SPE International Thermal Operations Symposium. Bakersfield, California, USA , 7-8 February.

table-wrap.anchoringText: This section will focus on summarizing the learnings from field tests and proposing some guidelines for designing future tests. Table 2 lists all the various tests in chronological order and Table 4 provides the main reservoir and fluid characteristics. In addition, Table 3 provides a summary of numerous single well field tests that have taken place in the Midway Sunset field (California) (Cooke & Eson, 1991).
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Reservoir and fluid characteristics

table-wrap.anchoringText: As indicated in Table 4 and Table 5, the steam foam process has been applied successfully in a wide variety of reservoir and fluid conditions. Note in particular the reservoir thickness which varies from less than 5 m (South Casper Creek) to 135 m (Dome Tumbador, Kern River). Oil viscosity also ranges from relatively medium viscosity (560 cp in Guadalupe) to bitumen (2,000,000 cp in Gregoire Lake).
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: Thermal injection type, issues and results summary

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thermal injection type, issues and results summary

table-wrap.anchoringText: One of the key learnings from the field tests is that both continuous and cyclic surfactant injection have been successfully employed. Continuous injection has achieved the highest incremental recovery but cyclic injection is more efficient in terms of incremental bbl per kg of surfactant (Table 6). This is why in the Gregoire Lake pilot for instance cyclic injection was tested after continuous injection in order to reduce surfactant requirements (Sander, Clark, & Lau, 1991).
table-wrap.label: Table 6
table-wrap.caption: Comparison of process efficiency

tr.th: Quantity of surfactant injected per well (kg)

table-wrap.anchoringText: A variety of surfactants have been used for the field trials. Table 7 provides a list of the main surfactants and their chemical natures while Table 8 lists the surfactants used in each test when information was available.
table-wrap.label: Table 7
table-wrap.caption: Chemical nature of main surfactants used in field tests

formatted-caption.caption-text: Chemical nature of main surfactants used in field tests

tr.td: Branched side chain dodecylbenzene sodium sulfonate
Branched C16-C18 alpha olefin sodium sulfonate

table-wrap.anchoringText: A variety of surfactants have been used for the field trials. Table 7 provides a list of the main surfactants and their chemical natures while Table 8 lists the surfactants used in each test when information was available.
table-wrap.label: Table 8
table-wrap.caption: Foam slug data

tr.th: Quantity of surfactant injected per well (kg)

tr.td: Siponate SD-10, later Neodene 1618, then Siponate A-168

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 6 Shows the quantities of surfactant for the field tests for which information is available. Injected surfactant volumes are much larger in continuous injection tests. Table 9 shows the quantities of surfactant injected per meter (net pay) of reservoir. There is too little information available for the cyclic injection and the figures are quite variable and but they can nonetheless be used to guide future pilot designs. The lowest values in Cymric, Winkleman Dome Nugget and Lagunillas suggest that good results can be obtained with 300 to 500 kg of surfactant per meter of pay.
table-wrap.label: Table 9
table-wrap.caption: Quantity of surfactant injected per meter of reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Quantity of surfactant injected per meter of reservoir

tr.th: Quantity of surfactant injected per well/meter of reservoir (kg/m)

table-wrap.anchoringText: The issue of temperature and in particular of the maximum applicable temperature for steam foam is very sensitive. As demonstrated by Table 10 and Figure 14, steam foam has mostly been used below 250°C. Of the tests above 250°C, one (Bachaquero) corresponds to cyclic injections (Robaina & Ziritt, 1988) for which surfactants stability is not as important; one (Cat Canyon) failed maybe due to temperature (Eson & Cook, 1989); and three over 300°C in Shengli correspond to high temperature gas foam with steam rather than to steam foam.
table-wrap.label: Table 10
table-wrap.caption: Main tests data

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 11 shows the tests when non condensable gas has been used and the corresponding quantities. As can be seen from the table the injection rates are quite variable but 20 scf/bbl of steam (CWE) seem to be the median value.
table-wrap.label: Table 11
table-wrap.caption: Non condensable gas

table-wrap.anchoringText: The first evidence of foam formation in the reservoir is the increase in injection pressure due to the reduced mobility of the steam. Table 12 lists the pressure responses and incremental oil production when information is available and Table 13 is a summary of all the pressure data available during the field tests. It is not easy to estimate the Mobility Reduction Factors during the tests but the changes in injection pressure can give a good idea of what can be expected.
table-wrap.label: Table 12
table-wrap.caption: Test responses

table-wrap.anchoringText: The first evidence of foam formation in the reservoir is the increase in injection pressure due to the reduced mobility of the steam. Table 12 lists the pressure responses and incremental oil production when information is available and Table 13 is a summary of all the pressure data available during the field tests. It is not easy to estimate the Mobility Reduction Factors during the tests but the changes in injection pressure can give a good idea of what can be expected.
table-wrap.label: Table 13
table-wrap.caption: Pressure data for field tests
